metadata.title: A comparative study of gelatin and starch-based nano-composite films modified by nano-cellulose and chitosan for food packaging applications

sections.text:

Carbohydrate Polymers

A comparative study of gelatin and starch-based nano-composite films modified by nano-cellulose and chitosan for food packaging applications
S.M. Noorbakhsh-Soltani, M.M. Zerafat⁎, S. Sabbaghi Faculty of Advanced Technologies, Nano-chemical Engineering Department, Shiraz University, Shiraz, Iran
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Nano-cellulose Chitosan Gelatin Starch Nanocomposite films Packaging
A B S T R A C T
Environmental concerns have led to extensive research for replacing polymer-based food packaging with bionano-composites. In this study, incorporation of nano-cellulose into gelatin and starch matrices is investigated for this purpose. Chitosan is used to improve mechanical, anti-fungal and waterproof properties. Experiments are designed and analyzed using response surface methodology. Nano-Cellulose is synthesized via acid hydrolysis and incorporated in base matrices through wet processing. Also, tensile strength test, food preservation, transparency in visible and UV and water contact angle are performed on the nano-composite films. DSC/TGA and air permeability tests are also performed on the optimal films. The results show that increasing nanocellulose composition to 10% leads to increase the tensile strength at break to 8121MN/m2 and decrease the elongation at break. Also, increasing chitosan composition from 5% to 30% can enhance food preservation up to 15 days.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The purpose of food packaging is prevention from contact of food materials with contaminating agents; physical, chemical or biological (Prasad & Kochhar, 2014), which is mainly performed through confining air and moisture availability. Glass, metal, paper, paperboard and various polymers including plastics have traditionally been implemented for this purpose (Tang, Kumar, Alavi, & Sandeep, 2012), among which plastics are considered as one of the main choices, during past decades due to processing convenience, high moisture and air resistance and low weight and cost properties (Accorsi, Cascini, Cholette, Manzini, & Mora, 2014). Various synthetic polymers are practiced for food packaging such as PVC, PA, PE, PET, PVA, etc. However, the growing demand for plastics has led to a global waste disposal crisis. The amount of plastic production in Europe has reached 311 Mt in 2014 with the highest demand in packaging industry (∼40%). Although plastic recycling has reached 69.2% but ∼8 Mt of plastic waste has been landfilled in European countries in 2014 (Plastics Europe Report, 2015).
Serious attempts have been made for replacement of synthetic polymers with relatively inexpensive, biodegradable and renewable material resources like natural polymers in food packaging application, though processing difficulties due to rigidity and stiffness has substantially hindered total and quick substitution. As a result, a deep need is felt for packaging films with biodegradable properties and yet
significant flexibility and mechanical strength which entails fabrication of natural polymer nano-composites (Wang & Funk, 2012).
Biodegradable polymers derived from renewable resources are highlighted as the future generation of packaging materials (Petersen et al., 1999), including Poly (lactic acid) (PLA), starch, cellulose, chitosan, agar, alginate and various proteins. Despite biodegradable characteristics, renewable biopolymers have certain drawbacks regarding performance and processing costs (Petersen et al., 1999). However, they are generally cheaper, abundant and edible in some cases (Bengtsson, Koch, & Gatenholm, 2003).
Several studies have been performed to analyze the properties of starch films produced from different botanical sources (Mali, Grossmann, García, Martino, & Zaritzky, 2002; Mali, Grossmann, García, Martino, & Zaritzky, 2004; Mali, Sakanaka, Yamashita, & Grossmann, 2005). Certain plasticizers may be added to starch films in order to decrease brittleness. Although, mechanical and barrier properties of starch films depend on moisture (Krochta & Mulder-Johnston, 1997), this can be solved by the introduction of hydrophobic components in order to improve water vapor sorption properties. For example, glycerol is added to starch (plasticized wheat starch: PWS) to enhance processability via conventional extrusion. Poor mechanical strength and high sensitivity to moisture can also be overcome by associating starch with moisture resistant polymers with good mechanical properties, while maintaining biodegradability. PWS has been melt-blended with various biodegradable polyesters, such as poly (lactic acid) (PLA)

(Martin & Avérous, 2001) and poly (butylene succinate adipate) (PBSA) (Avérous & Fringant, 2001) resulting in a significant improvement in properties.
Reduced water vapor transport is among important factors in the performance of starch as a packaging material which can be achieved through blending with polymers like chitosan. The higher hydrophobicity of chitosan compared with strach causes the film to obtain higher ressitance toward moisture along with the enhancement of mechanical strength. Strach-chitosan composite films are produced with improved trasnport properties and also the reduction of elongation to break and the enhancement of mechanical strength (Lopez et al., 2014). Chitosan has animicrobial properties besides biodegradability and intoxicity (Dutta, Tripathi Sh Mehrotra, & Dutta, 2009). While chitosan leads to the reduction of vapor transport, glycerol has an opposite effect. Also, glycerol results in the reduction of mechanical strength (Chillo et al., 2008; Pelissari, Grossmann, Yamashita, & Pineda, 2009).
Gelatin is another renewable polymer which has long been used as a packaging material consisting of a glued network of microcrystalline segments (Slade & Levine, 1988). Gelatin-Chitosan edible films with good mechanical strength and transport properties are prepared (Arvanitoyannis, Nakayama, & Aiba, 1998).
Addition of various nanomaterials to polymeric matrices has been another solution for the improvement of the desired packaging properties. Nano-clays have been added to various polymeric matrices in very small quantities (generally< 5wt%) to improve film properties. Other nano-fillers have also been introduced to induce higher mechanical strength and barrier against gases and water vapor (Ghanbarzadeh, Oleyaei, & Almasi, 2015). Nano-fillers are capable of improving barrier and mechanical properties by decreasing filler dimensions and also reducing production cost due to lower material consumption (Rhim, Park, & Ha, 2013). Moreover, Nano-filler reinforcement leads to changes in polymer crystallinity (Azeredo, Mattoso, & McHugh, 2011). Mechanical strength and transport properties of chitosan-clay biodegradable films are investigated at various nano-clay proportions. Nano-clay leads to reduced transport and enhanced water absorption (Giannakas, Grigoriadi, Leontiou, Barkoula, & Ladavos, 2014). The addition of nanoclay to starch composite films has improved the mechanical strength and transport properties (Tang, 2008). Zeolites are also used as fillers in starch-based films. Studies show that zeolite leads to the enhancement of Young modulus and reduction of gas and vapor transport and also water solubility (Belibi et al., 2013).
Cellulose is another semi-crystalline high Mw natural nano-polymer virtually present in all plants with typical crystal lengths of 20–2000 nm. Even though the tensile properties of nano-crystalline cellulose are an order of magnitude below those of carbon nanotubes they are sufficiently high to justify them as fillers in bio-composite materials (Rousseau & Tolnai, 2010). Cellulose fibers are added to gelatin-based films enhancing film strength up to 5% (Santos et al., 2014). Nano-cellulose is also added to starch in order to enhance starch film properties. Based on the results, nano-cellulose leads to the improvement of mechanical properties up to 70% (Nasri-Nasrabadi et al., 2014).
Based on the literature review performed, a systematic study on the effect of nano-cellulose and chitosan on packaging performance of gelatin and starch-based nano-composite films is not performed. So, this study is aimed at the improvement of mechanical strength and barrier properties of gelatin and starch-based nano-composite films by incorporating various chitosan and nano-cellulose proportions in the host matrix. Based on the studies, it is expected that addition of nano-cellulose to the mixed polymeric matrix bring about mechanical strength as well as improved food preservation characteristics to gelatin and starch films.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Starch (ρ=0.625 g/cm3) and cellulose micro-fibrills (ρ=0.6 g/ cm3) were purchased from Sigma-aldrich. Chitosan (Mw=60000–80000 g/gmol, ρ=0.3 g/cm3) is provided by Acros Co. Gelatin (ρ=0.98 g/cm3) and other reagents are also provided by Merck Co.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Synthesis of nano-cellulose
sections.text:
Cellulose nano-crystals are obtained via acidic hydrolysis of cellulose microcrystals by dissolution of semi-crystalline regions in sulfuric acid and re-dispersion of the remaining materials in water. Details of the synthesis procedure can be found elsewhere (Abdollahi, Alboofetileh, Behrooz, Rezaei, & Miraki, 2013; Zhao et al., 2014)
2.2.2. Preparation of nano-composite films Single-layered films are prepared through film casting technique. A certain amount of chitosan is dissolved in a 10mL of 2 V/V% acetic acid solution under stirring for 10–15min producing a transparent solution. Also, a certain amount of nano-cellulose gel is dispersed in 20mL deionized water and sonicated (200W) for 10min producing a homogeneous dispersion. A certain amount of polymeric base (starch or gelatin) is added to the mixed solution.
For starch films, the solution is heated to 60 °C and stirred vigorously for 10min to produce a gelatinous solution. For gelatin films, the solution is heated to 40 °C and stirred vigorously for 15min until total dissolution occurs. The separate solutions based on the polymer base and chitosan are mixed at 45 °C and glycerol is also added to the mixture and ultra-sonicated (50W) for 2min. The final solution is dried in oven at 55 °C for 12 h.
Double-layered films are prepared by producing the polymer base and chitosan solutions separately using the same procedure as stated in the preparation of single-layered films except that glycerol and nanocellulose are added regarding dry mass of polymer and chitosan then ultra-sonicated separately. Here, first the chitosan layer is cast and dried. Thereafter, the starch or gelatin layers are coated over the first layer and dried in oven at 55 °C for 10 h.

sections.heading: 2.2.3. Design of experiments
sections.text: Several parameters such as nano-cellulose composition, chitosan content, type of polymeric base and its weight% and glycerol content may influence the performance of nano-composite films to various degrees. As a result, these parameters are intended for optimization using a design of experiments procedure namely Response Surface Methodology (RSM), the results of which are shown in Table 1 as 24 individual experiments.

sections.heading: 2.2.4. Characterization
sections.text:
X-ray diffraction (XRD) is performed on cellulose nano/micro crystals to determine the variations in structure and crystallite size. Also, TEM micrographs are used to determine the size and morphology of nano-cellulose. Cellulose microcrystals are also observed using SEM technique. XRD equipment (D8 ADVANCE, BRUKER Germany) is used to perform XRD analysis.
Cellulose crystal micrographs were characterized using SEM (TESCAN-Mira III, Czceh Republic). Philips CM-30 was also implemented to perform TEM analysis. DSC/TGA and air permeability tests are also performed on the optimal efficiency films.

sections.text:

Based on the XRD spectrum, hydrolysis results in peak height enhancement at 2Ө=15.30 & 22.60 values and also increasing width at mid maximum height showing improved crystallinity and size reduction according to Debye-Scherer eq. sections.heading: 3.1.2. TEM and SEM analyses of cellulose nano-whiskers
sections.text:
Fig. 2 shows the TEM and SEM micrographs of cellulose nanowhisker gel indicating individual nano-whiskers with an average length>100 nm and average diameter> 10 nm.
3.2. Characterization of nano-composite films

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Tensile strength
sections.text:
Investigation of mechanical properties of the nano-composite films are performed based on the variations in the composition of constituent
materials and their type using ASTM D638-02a tensile test standard. CT3 texture analyzer is used to perform the tensile strength tests. This can be used to measure the elongation at break and tensile strength at break for various films. The results of Young modulus analysis are categorized in three separate sections: (1) Young modulus analysis at 23 °C, (2) Tensile strength at break and, (3) Strain analysis at break.
Based on the results regarding the mechanical strength of nanocomposite films (stress-strain curves), samples 4, 8, 11, 13, 15, 19 and 21–24 show a thinning while samples 1, 3, 5–7, 9, 10, 12, 17, 18, 20 show thickening while others show a simple linear behavior. Most of the samples fall in the category of soft plastics approaching hard plastic behavior by increasing the nano-cellulose composition (Fig. 3 & Table 1).
3.2.1.1. Young modulus at 23 °C. Table 2 shows the Young modulus for samples 1–24 calculated using the measured stress-strain curves (Fig. 3). The results are analyzed using design expert software. Detailed analysis of the results in an ANOVA table shows a Pvalue< 0.05 and the model is significant. Based on the results, increasing chitosan content in the synthesized film results in the enhancement of Young modulus reaching a constant value which is expected due to the higher strength nature of chitosan compared with starch and gelatin. Increasing the nano-cellulose content over 8% results in reduced Young modulus values due to agglomeration and development of cellulose-cellulose physical interactions (Fig. 4). The highest Young modulus is practiced for sample 19 at a 10% NCC content for gelatin. 3.2.1.2. Tensile strength at break. Tensile strength at break is measured for each sample as an average of 5 measurements (Table 2). The results are analyzed using Design Expert software. Detailed analysis of the results in an ANOVA table shows a P-value<0.05 and the model is significant. The results show that increasing chitosan content in the synthesized film leads to the enhancement of tensile strength reaching a constant value. Increasing the nano-cellulose content after 8% results in reduced tensile strength again due to agglomeration and cellulosecellulose interactions.
3.2.1.3. Strain at break (Elongation%). Strain analysis is performed at the break point reported as an average of 5 measurements (Table 2). The results are analyzed using Design Expert software. Fig. 5 shows the variations of Elongation% as a function of chitosan composition. Based on this figure, elongation at break is reduced by increasing chitosan content in both gelatin and starch films. As it is expected, elongation at break is always lower for starch films. This can be attributed to chitosan characteristics which show a brittle nature in spite of its high Young modulus (Martínez-Camacho et al., 2010). The highest strain at break is reported for sample 17 as 221.37 (gelatin without cellulose) and the lowest for sample 21 as 41.14 (gelatin with 10% cellulose). This brittle behavior is expected due to the rigid behavior of NCC compared with gelatin.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Food preservation
sections.text:
Durability test is performed on the synthesized films changing composition and the polymeric base. Certain number of pomegranate seeds are packed in the produced films and preserved at 25 °C and 55% relative humidity. Durability is reported as the time required for the emergence of apparent fungal growth on the samples or loss of integrity. Samples are checked every 3 h repeated for every sample for 3 times and the results are reported as an average value. Fungi is grown on the control sample after 5 days and the sample seeds packed in polyethylene sheets after 9 days but no fungal growth was observed on the sample packed in the produced films during the test period (14 days). Table 2 has summarized the durability test results for samples 1–24.
Fig. 6 shows the effect of glycerol content on food preservation characteristics. Based on the results, increasing the glycerol content to 2.16mL in 1 g dry film results in the enhancement of food quality starting to decrease from that point on, attributed to the enhancement of relative humidity preventing the food to lose moisture. This may in turn result in the destruction of film structure and porosity enhancement leading to fast moisture loss and quality reduction.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Contact angle (CA) measurements
sections.text:
The importance of CA in food packaging applications is originated from the fact that CA is an indication of hydrophobicity/hydrophilicity character of the film. Hydrophilic character leads to food stagnation
and quality reduction which must be prevented. The results of CA measurement for samples 1–24 are summarized in Table 2.
Fig. 7 shows the effect of nano-cellulose content on film-water contact angle at 5% and 30% chitosan contents, respectively. Based on the results, nano-cellulose content is not significant in the film contact angle which is promising due to high hydrophilic character of cellulose. Also, higher chitosan contents favor hydrophobicity reaching a constant value which is promising.

sections.heading: 3.2.4. Visible light transparency
sections.text: Transparency is one of the measures of film quality from its appearance. Table 2 shows the transparency analysis results for samples 1–24 measured using UV spectrophotometry. This must be noticed that transparency is somehow a function of sample color measured as a function of light transmittance. The results show that by increasing NCC composition up to 6% dry weight, transparency is increased and starts to decrease after that which may be attributed to the agglomeration of nano-whiskers resulting in the scattering of light and loss of transparency. The most transparent film is occurred at [Base: chitosan: Cellulose]= [Gelatin: 15:10] (sample 19) as ∼84% and the lowest at [Base: chitosan: Cellulose]= [Starch: 19: 0] (sample 6) as 35.67.

sections.heading: 4. Optimization and comparison of the results
sections.text:
Several optimum set of parameters exist which satisfy the desired packaging properties from which different sets can be selected for various applications. An example can be represented as follows: NCC=9.46%, chitosan=30%, glycerol= 0.5mL based on the starch films with 0.713 desirability. For this sample, Young Modulus= 18.37 GPa, tensile strength= 2165.4MPa, elongation to break= 76.56%, quality reduction rate per pomegranate seed=6.88 h/ number, contact angle=∼84.320, transparency=0.88 and UV transparency=10.45%. This sample was also built as a two-layered film and the results were compared with the single-layered version. Based on the results, the double layered film has a higher food preservation and contact angle due to higher chitosan content compared with the single layered film. The strength is decreased but not significantly possibly due to the looser interaction at the interface of two layers. Light transmittance is also decreased slightly with a UV transparency reduction of ∼39%.
Also, two samples with the same conditions as the optimum reported sample but with different bases (Opt1 and Opt2) were selected to perform thermal stability and air permeability tests with results reported in Sections 4.1 and 4.2. These samples were selected for further characterizations which are suggested by Design Expert having good
mechanical strength and acceptable appearance for packaging applications (NCC=10%, Chitosan=30% with corresponding bases).

sections.heading: 4.1. Thermal stability
sections.text:
Differential Scanning Colorimetry (DSC) and Thermal Gravity Analysis (TGA) tests are performed on the optimal samples to investigate the thermal stability of the films and also thermo-mechanical propeties (Tg). Fig. 8(a, b) shows the TGA and DSC analyses results for Opt1 and Opt2 samples. Fig. 8(a) gives a combined representation of TGA curves for Opt1 and Opt2. Based on the figure, at the first stage of the curve for Opt 1 a primary small mass reduction is observed by increasing the temperature due to moisture and volatiles evaporation. Then from 230 °C to 360 °C significant mass reduction and decomposition is occurred which is also approved by DSC curve in Fig. 8(b) (Mathew, Brahmakumar, & Abraham, 2006; Liu, Yu, Liu, Chen, & Li, 2009). Also, in DSC curve for Opt1 (Fig. 8(b)), the first stage is grown with two endothermic steps. In this section, the curve gives two Tg values at 51.53 (for chitosan) and 69.71 °C (for starch). Also, over Tg an exothermic process is observed which can be attributed to molecular relaxation (Rahman and Al-Saidi, 2010; Rotta, Minatti, & Baret, 2011; Liu, Bhandari, & Zhou, 2007).
In Fig. 8(a) for gelatin-based nanocomposite (Opt1), increasing the temperature results in primary moisture evaporation and decomposition is started from 160 °C and continued up to 385 °C (Rao, 2007; Sakurai, Maegawa, & Takahashi, 2000). Prompt changes in the DSC curve also shows (Fig. 8(b) for Opt2) the Tg values as 51.94 °C (for chitosan) and 75.85 °C (for gelatin). Over the Tg of gelatin, molecular relaxation is observed in the 89–119 °C temperature range (Hosseini, Rezaei, Zandi, & Farahmand Ghavi, 2013; Forssella, Mikkilti, Moates, & Parker, 1997; Liu et al., 2007). Around 120 °C a recrystallization peak is observed and at around 243 °C melting of the nanocomposite occurs. Based on the TGA curves (Fig. 8(a)), both samples show good thermal stability up to 100 °C, alhough the gelatin-based samples shows a somehow faster decomposition rate at higher temperatures.

sections.heading: 4.2. Air permeability
sections.text: Air permeability test is performed on the optimal films (Opt1 and Opt2) with a 0.15mm thickness and 0.8495 cm2 at 25 °C. The results of air permeability are 0.26 cm3(STP).cm/cm2.s.cmHg for Opt1 and 0.17 cm3(STP) cm/cm2 s cmHg for Opt2. Based on the results, the gelatin-based nanocomposite shows a lower air permeability value (35% lower) as expected due to the higher crystallinity of gelatin.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this study, NCC was used as a nano-scale additive into the starchchitosan and gelatin-chitosan nano-composite films. Chitosan was used to enhance antibacterial and anti-fungal properties. The most important conclusions can be summarized as follows:
(1) Enhancement of nano-cellulose content to 8%, results in the improvement of Young modulus, tensile strength, elongation to break, transparency and somehow food preservation characteristics in both gelatin and starch bases. (2) Enhancement of chitosan content, results in the improvement of young modulus, tensile strength, food preservation, transparency in gelatin films and contact angle in starch films and also the reduction of UV transmittance. (3) Transparency, tensile strength and elongation to break in gelatin films are higher compared with starch films. Also, food preservation and contact angle are higher in starch films. (4) Increasing glycerol content results in the enhancement of elongation to break and reduction of Young modulus and tensile strength. Also, glycerol results in improvement of food durability and contact
angle to an optimal point after which the trend is reversed. (5) The optimal films have a good thermal stability up to 100 °C and
also a low air permeability (35% lower for the gelatin-based film) which is promising for packaging applications.

referenceMentions.context: Biodegradable polymers derived from renewable resources are highlighted as the future generation of packaging materials (Petersen et al., 1999), including Poly (lactic acid) (PLA), starch, cellulose, chitosan, agar, alginate and various proteins.
Despite biodegradable characteristics, renewable biopolymers have certain drawbacks regarding performance and processing costs (Petersen et al., 1999).
Strach-chitosan composite films are produced with improved trasnport properties and also the reduction of elongation to break and the enhancement of mechanical strength (Lopez et al., 2014).
Also, glycerol results in the reduction of mechanical strength (Chillo et al., 2008; Pelissari, Grossmann, Yamashita, & Pineda, 2009).
The addition of nanoclay to starch composite films has improved the mechanical strength and transport properties (Tang, 2008).
Studies show that zeolite leads to the enhancement of Young modulus and reduction of gas and vapor transport and also water solubility (Belibi et al., 2013).
Cellulose fibers are added to gelatin-based films enhancing film strength up to 5% (Santos et al., 2014).
Based on the results, nano-cellulose leads to the improvement of mechanical properties up to 70% (Nasri-Nasrabadi et al., 2014).
Details of the synthesis procedure can be found elsewhere (Abdollahi, Alboofetileh, Behrooz, Rezaei, & Miraki, 2013; Zhao et al., 2014)
This can be attributed to chitosan characteristics which show a brittle nature in spite of its high Young modulus (Martínez-Camacho et al., 2010).
Also, over Tg an exothermic process is observed which can be attributed to molecular relaxation (Rahman and Al-Saidi, 2010; Rotta, Minatti, & Baret, 2011; Liu, Bhandari, & Zhou, 2007).

8(a) for gelatin-based nanocomposite (Opt1), increasing the temperature results in primary moisture evaporation and decomposition is started from 160 °C and continued up to 385 °C (Rao, 2007; Sakurai, Maegawa, & Takahashi, 2000).

Over the Tg of gelatin, molecular relaxation is observed in the 89–119 °C temperature range (Hosseini, Rezaei, Zandi, & Farahmand Ghavi, 2013; Forssella, Mikkilti, Moates, & Parker, 1997; Liu et al., 2007).

metadata.abstractText: Environmental concerns have led to extensive research for replacing polymer-based food packaging with bionano-composites. In this study, incorporation of nano-cellulose into gelatin and starch matrices is investigated for this purpose. Chitosan is used to improve mechanical, anti-fungal and waterproof properties. Experiments are designed and analyzed using response surface methodology. Nano-Cellulose is synthesized via acid hydrolysis and incorporated in base matrices through wet processing. Also, tensile strength test, food preservation, transparency in visible and UV and water contact angle are performed on the nano-composite films. DSC/TGA and air permeability tests are also performed on the optimal films. The results show that increasing nanocellulose composition to 10% leads to increase the tensile strength at break to 8121MN/m and decrease the elongation at break.
